Cowasjee Dinshaw & Brothers. Sir Hormusjee, who is now 82 years old, has for several years resided in Bombay, leaving the local management of his business in Aden to his sons, but at my invitation, he has now paid a special visit to Aden on the occasion of the Centenary. Since his arrival he has spoken to me about his continued apprehension regarding the future of the Aden Salt Industry, in which he and many of his friends are deeply interested. He has given me a Note that was drawn up by him and them in Bombay on this subject in the hope that I might find it possible to make some public reference to this question during the Centenary Celebrations. I have not thought it appropriate to do so, and I have told Sir Hormusjee that I consider it better and more likely to be effective if I were to infoim you of the representations that he has made to me. 2. mods.abstract: This file contains a letter from Bernard Rawdon Reilly (Governor and Commander-in-Chief of Aden) to Malcolm MacDonald (Secretary of State for the Colonies), and a reply from MacDonald to Reilly. The correspondence relates to the concerns of Sir Hormusjee Cowasjee Dinshaw about the future of the Aden Salt Industry. These items were forwarded to the India Office in May 1939.
